current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To award a Congressional Gold Medal to Pat Summitt, in recognition of her remarkable career as an unparalleled figure in women's team sports, and for her courage in speaking out openly and courageously about her battle with Alzheimer's.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text: Pat Summitt Congressional Gold Medal Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

Pat Summitt, who has more wins than any
basketball coach in NCAA history, men or women,
concluded her coaching career after 38 seasons at the University of Tennessee on April 18, 2012.

Pat Summitt won a record eight NCAA
championships, and received National Coach of the
Year honors 7 times over her career.
Pat Summitt will remain head coach emeritus at the University of Tennessee, mentoring and teaching life skills to players.

Coaching has been the great passion of Pat
Summitt’s life, and the job has always been an opportunity for her to work with student-athletes and
help them discover their true potential.

Coach Summitt’s last team at the University of Tennessee finished with an overall record of
27–9, including an SEC Tournament Championship
and a spot in the Final Four in Denver.

Pat Summitt continued her work off the court, including a graduation record of 100 percent
for all Lady Vols who completed their eligibility at
the University of Tennessee.
Pat Summitt announced on August 23, 2011, that she had been diagnosed with early onset dementia,
Later in November 2011, Coach Summitt announced the Pat Summitt Foundation Fund, which helps to provide funding and research for Alzheimer’s and dementia.

On May 29, 2012, President Barack Obama awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the country’s highest civilian honor, to Pat Summitt for her remarkable career as an unparalleled figure in women’s team sports, and for her courage in speaking out openly and courageously about her battle with Alzheimer’s.

for the presentation, on behalf of the Congress, of a gold
medal of appropriate design to Pat Summitt, in recognition of her remarkable career as an unparalleled figure
in women’s team sports, and for her courage in speaking
out openly and courageously about her battle with Alzheimer’s.
